rng.h
1 #ifndef RNG_H
2 #define RNG_H
3 
4 // __________________________________________________________________________
5 // rng.h - a Random Number Generator Class
6 // rng.C - contains the non-inline class methods
7 
8 // __________________________________________________________________________
9 // CAUTIONS:
10 
11 // 1. Some of this code might not work correctly on 64-bit machines. I
12 // have hacked the 32 bit version try and make it work, but the 64-bit
13 // version is not extensively tested.
14 //
15 // 2. This generator should NOT be used as in the following line.
16 // for (int i = 0; i < 100; ++i) { RNG x; cout << x.uniform() << endl; }
17 // The problem is that each time through the loop, a new RNG 'x' is
18 // created, and that RNG is used to generate exactly one random number.
19 // While the results may be satisfactory, the class is designed to
20 // produce quality random numbers by having a single (or a few) RNGs
21 // called repeatedly.
22 // The better way to do the above loop is:
23 // RNG x; for (int i = 0; i < 100; ++i) { cout << x.uniform() << endl; }
24 
25 // __________________________________________________________________________
26 // This C++ code uses the simple, fast "KISS" (Keep It Simple Stupid)
27 // random number generator suggested by George Marsaglia in a Usenet
28 // posting from 1999. He describes it as "one of my favorite
29 // generators". It generates high-quality random numbers that
30 // apparently pass all commonly used tests for randomness. In fact, it
31 // generates random numbers by combining the results of three simple
32 // random number generators that have different periods and are
33 // constructed from completely different algorithms. It does not have
34 // the ultra-long period of some other generators - a "problem" that can
35 // be fixed fairly easily - but that seems to be its only potential
36 // problem. The period is about 2^123.
37 
38 // The KISS algorithm is only used directly in the function rand_int32.
39 // rand_int32 is then used (directly or indirectly) by every other
40 // member function of the class that generates random numbers. For
41 // faster random numbers, one can redefine rand_int32 to return either
42 // WMC(), CONG(), or SHR3(). The speed will be two to three times
43 // faster, and the quality of the random numbers should be sufficient
44 // for many purposes. The three alternatives are comparable in terms of
45 // both speed and quality.
46 
47 // The ziggurat method of Marsaglia is used to generate exponential and
48 // normal variates. The method as well as source code can be found in
49 // the article "The Ziggurat Method for Generating Random Variables" by
50 // Marsaglia and Tsang, Journal of Statistical Software 5, 2000.
51 
52 // The method for generating gamma variables appears in "A Simple Method
53 // for Generating Gamma Variables" by Marsaglia and Tsang, ACM
54 // Transactions on Mathematical Software, Vol. 26, No 3, Sep 2000, pages
55 // 363-372.
56 // __________________________________________________________________________
57

59 #include <ctime>

61 #include <climits>

68 static const double PI = 3.1415926535897932;
69 static const double AD_l = 0.6931471805599453;
70 static const double AD_a = 5.7133631526454228;
71 static const double AD_b = 3.4142135623730950;
72 static const double AD_c = -1.6734053240284925;
73 static const double AD_p = 0.9802581434685472;
74 static const double AD_A = 5.6005707569738080;
75 static const double AD_B = 3.3468106480569850;
76 static const double AD_H = 0.0026106723602095;
77 static const double AD_D = 0.0857864376269050;

79 typedef signed int sint;
80 typedef unsigned int uint;
81 typedef signed long slong;
82 typedef unsigned long ulong;
83 #if ULONG_MAX == 4294967295ul
84 inline ulong ULONG32(slong x) { return (ulong(x)); }
85 inline ulong ULONG32(ulong x) { return (ulong(x)); }
86 inline ulong ULONG32(double x) { return (ulong(x)); }
87 inline slong UL32toSL32(ulong x) { return (slong(x)); }
88 #else
89 inline ulong ULONG32(slong x) { return (ulong(x) & 0xfffffffful); }
90 inline ulong ULONG32(ulong x) { return (x & 0xfffffffful); }
91 inline ulong ULONG32(double x) { return (ulong(x) & 0xfffffffful); }
92 inline slong UL32toSL32(ulong x)
93  { return (x < 0x80000000ul ? slong(x) : -1 * (0x80000000ul - (x & 0x7ffffffful))); }
94 #endif
95 
96 class RNG
97 {
98  private:
99  ulong z, w, jsr, jcong; // Seeds
100 
101  static ulong tm; // Used to ensure different RNGs have different seeds.
102  static ulong kn[128], ke[256];
103  static double wn[128], fn[128], we[256],fe[256];
104 
105  public:
106  RNG() { init(); zigset(); }
107  RNG(ulong x_) :
108  z(x_), w(x_), jsr(x_), jcong(x_) {zigset(); }
109  RNG(ulong z_, ulong w_, ulong jsr_, ulong jcong_ ) :
110  z(z_), w(w_), jsr(jsr_), jcong(jcong_) { zigset(); }
111  ~RNG() { }
112 
113 #if ULONG_MAX == 4294967295ul
114  // 32 bit unsigned longs
115  ulong znew()
116  { return (z = 36969 * (z & 0xfffful) + (z >> 16)); }
117  ulong wnew()
118  { return (w = 18000 * (w & 0xfffful) + (w >> 16)); }
119  ulong MWC()
120  { return ((znew() << 16) + wnew()); }
121  ulong SHR3()
122  { jsr ^= (jsr << 17); jsr ^= (jsr >> 13); return (jsr ^= (jsr << 5)); }
123  ulong CONG()
124  { return (jcong = 69069 * jcong + 1234567); }
125  ulong rand_int32() // [0,2^32-1]
126  { return ((MWC() ^ CONG()) + SHR3()); }
127  ulong rand_int() // [0,2^32-1]
128  { return ((MWC() ^ CONG()) + SHR3()); }
129 #elif ULONG_MAX == 18446744073709551615ul
130 #ifdef RNG_C
131 #warning "Compiling RNG class for 64-bit architecture"
132 #endif
133  // 64-bit unsigned longs
134  // This is not as elegant and fast as it could be, but it works.
135  ulong znew()
136  { return (z = ((36969 * (z & 0xfffful) + (z >> 16)) & 0xfffffffful)); }
137  ulong wnew()
138  { return (w = ((18000 * (w & 0xfffful) + (w >> 16)) & 0xfffffffful)); }
139  ulong MWC()
140  { return (((znew() << 16) + wnew()) & 0xfffffffful); }
141 // ulong SHR3()
142 // { jsr ^= (jsr << 17); jsr ^= (jsr >> 13);
143 // return (jsr = ((jsr ^= (jsr << 5)) & 0xfffffffful)); }
144  ulong SHR3()
145  { jsr ^= (jsr << 17); jsr ^= (jsr >> 13); jsr ^= (jsr << 5);
146  return (jsr &= 0xfffffffful); }
147  ulong CONG()
148  { return (jcong = ((69069 * jcong + 1234567) & 0xfffffffful)); }
149  ulong rand_int32() // [0,2^32-1]
150  { return (((MWC() ^ CONG()) + SHR3()) & 0xfffffffful); }
151  ulong rand_int() // [0,2^64-1]
152  { return (rand_int32() | (rand_int32() << 32)); }
153 #endif
154  double RNOR() {
155  slong h = UL32toSL32(rand_int32()), i = h & 127;
156  return (((ulong)std::abs(h) < kn[i]) ? h * wn[i] : nfix(h, i));
157  }
158  double REXP() {
159  ulong j = rand_int32(), i = j & 255;
160  return ((j < ke[i]) ? j * we[i] : efix(j, i));
161  }
162 
163  double nfix(slong h, ulong i);
164  double efix(ulong j, ulong i);
165  void zigset();
166 
167  void init()
168  { z = w = jsr = jcong = ulong(time(0)) + tm; tm += 123457; }
169  void init(ulong z_, ulong w_, ulong jsr_, ulong jcong_ )
170  { z = z_; w = w_; jsr = jsr_; jcong = jcong_; }
171 
172  // For a faster but lower quality RNG, uncomment the following
173  // line, and comment out the original definition of rand_int above.
174  // In practice, the faster RNG will be fine for simulations
175  // that do not simulate more than a few billion random numbers.
176  // ulong rand_int() { return SHR3(); }
177  long rand_int31() // [0,2^31-1]
178  { return ((long) rand_int32() >> 1);}
179  double rand_closed01() // [0,1]
180  { return ((double) rand_int() / double(ULONG_MAX)); }
181  double rand_open01() // (0,1)
182  { return (((double) rand_int() + 1.0) / (ULONG_MAX + 2.0)); }
183  double rand_halfclosed01() // [0,1)
184  { return ((double) rand_int() / (ULONG_MAX + 1.0)); }
185  double rand_halfopen01() // (0,1]
186  { return (((double) rand_int() + 1.0) / (ULONG_MAX + 1.0)); }
187 
188  // Continuous Distributions
189  double uniform(double x = 0.0, double y = 1.0)
190  { return rand_closed01() * (y - x) + x; }
191  double normal(double mu = 0.0, double sd = 1.0)
192  { return RNOR() * sd + mu; }
193  double exponential(double lambda = 1)
194  { return REXP() / lambda; }
195  double gamma(double shape = 1, double scale = 1);
196  double chi_square(double df)
197  { return gamma(df / 2.0, 0.5); }
198  double beta(double a1, double a2)
199  { const double x1 = gamma(a1, 1); return (x1 / (x1 + gamma(a2, 1))); }
200 
201  void uniform(std::vector<double>& res, double x = 0.0, double y = 1.0) {
202  for (std::vector<double>::iterator i = res.begin(); i != res.end(); ++i)
203  *i = uniform(x, y);
204  }
205  void normal(std::vector<double>& res, double mu = 0.0, double sd = 1.0) {
206  for (std::vector<double>::iterator i = res.begin(); i != res.end(); ++i)
207  *i = normal(mu, sd);
208  }
209  void exponential(std::vector<double>& res, double lambda = 1) {
210  for (std::vector<double>::iterator i = res.begin(); i != res.end(); ++i)
211  *i = exponential(lambda);
212  }
213  void gamma(std::vector<double>& res, double shape = 1, double scale = 1) {
214  for (std::vector<double>::iterator i = res.begin(); i != res.end(); ++i)
215  *i = gamma(shape, scale);
216  }
217  void chi_square(std::vector<double>& res, double df) {
218  for (std::vector<double>::iterator i = res.begin(); i != res.end(); ++i)
219  *i = chi_square(df);
220  }
221  void beta(std::vector<double>& res, double a1, double a2) {
222  for (std::vector<double>::iterator i = res.begin(); i != res.end(); ++i)
223  *i = beta(a1, a2);
224  }
225 
226  // Discrete Distributions
227  int poisson(double mu);
228  int binomial(double p, int n);
229  void multinom(unsigned int n, const std::vector<double>& probs, std::vector<uint>& samp);
230  void multinom(unsigned int n, const double* prob, uint K, uint* samp);
231  //Added June 2011
232  void multinom(uint size, const double* probs, uint num_probs, uint* samp, uint &maxS);
233  //Added August 2011
234  //Size 1 sample
235  void multinom(const double* probs, uint num_probs, uint &sample);
236 
237 
238  void poisson(std::vector<int>& res, double lambda) {
239  for (std::vector<int>::iterator i = res.begin(); i != res.end(); ++i)
240  *i = poisson(lambda);
241  }
242  void binomial(std::vector<int>& res, double p, int n) {
243  for (std::vector<int>::iterator i = res.begin(); i != res.end(); ++i)
244  *i = binomial(p, n);
245  }

247 }; // class RNG
